completion:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT
DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Adams

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 28-year-old female who presents with persistent cough and hilar adenopathy.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

D86.0 Sarcoidosis of lung

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

D86.0 Sarcoidosis of lung

PROCEDURE

31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s) 
31628 TBBX single lobe 
31652 EBUS sampling 1 or 2 nodes 
31654 Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion 
76982 Ultrasound Elastography, First Target Lesion 
76983 Ultrasound Elastography, Additional Targets 

ATTENDING Dr. Chen

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope, Linear EBUS, Radial EBUS.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location.
Patient Position: Supine.

Initial Airway Inspection: NBI was used to assess the airway and nodular changes were noted.
Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the Lingula Superior (LB4) and Inferior (LB5).
Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.
Samples were sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.
Endobronchial Biopsy: Endobronchial biopsy was performed at RUL Carina (RC1) and RLL Carina (RC6).
Lesions were successfully removed and samples sent for Pathology.

Radial EBUS & Transbronchial Biopsy: Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the lesion in the RLL is concentric.
The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Superior Segment of RLL (RB6).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.
Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle, 19-gauge Needle, and Cryoprobe 1.1mm.
Lymph Nodes Inspected: 4R, 4L, 7, 10R, 10L, 11Rs, 11Ri, 11L.
Lymph Nodes Evaluated & Sampled:

Station 7 (Subcarinal): The node was ≥ 10 mm on CT.
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics.
The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 2 elastographic pattern with mixed soft and stiff regions.
Given this heterogeneous and indeterminate appearance, TBNA was directed at representative areas.
The lymph node was photographed and the site was sampled;
8 endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained.

Station 11L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Station 4L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

EBBX, TBBX
BAL
Station 7 - TBCBX, TBNA 

IMPRESSION/PLAN

28-year-old female with persistent cough and hilar adenopathy.

Follow up in clinic.

prompt: Please generate an IP op note for a 46 year old female with persistent cough and hilar adenopathy. We did a BAL at the Lateral Segment of RML and EBBX at multiple carinas. Used radial EBUS for a RLL lesion, taking biopsies. Staged mediastinum, sampled Station 4R which was Type 2, skipped the smaller nodes.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location.
Patient Position: Supine.

Initial Airway Inspection: NBI was used to assess the airway and nodular changes were noted.
Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the Lingula Superior (LB4) and Inferior (LB5).
Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.
Samples were sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.
Endobronchial Biopsy: Endobronchial biopsy was performed at RUL Carina (RC1) and RLL Carina (RC6).
Lesions were successfully removed and samples sent for Pathology.

Radial EBUS & Transbronchial Biopsy: Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the lesion in the RUL is concentric.
The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Apical Segment of RUL (RB1).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.
Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle, 19-gauge Needle, and Cryoprobe 1.1mm.
Lymph Nodes Inspected: 4R, 4L, 7, 10R, 10L, 11Rs, 11Ri, 11L.
Lymph Nodes Evaluated & Sampled:

Station 4L (Left Lower Paratracheal): The node was ≥ 10 mm on CT.
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics.
The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 3 elastographic pattern with predominantly stiff (blue).
Given this suspicious for malignancy or granuloma, TBNA was directed at representative areas.
The lymph node was photographed and the site was sampled;
8 endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained.

Station 10R: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Station 11L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope, Linear EBUS, Radial EBUS.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location.
Patient Position: Supine.

Initial Airway Inspection: NBI was used to assess the airway and nodular changes were noted.
Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the RLL Superior Segment (RB6).
Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.
Samples were sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.
Endobronchial Biopsy: Endobronchial biopsy was performed at Main Carina and RML Carina (RC2).
Lesions were successfully removed and samples sent for Pathology.

Radial EBUS & Transbronchial Biopsy: Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the lesion in the LUL is concentric.
The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Apico-posterior Segment of LUL (LB1+2).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.
Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle, 19-gauge Needle, and Cryoprobe 1.1mm.
Lymph Nodes Inspected: 4R, 4L, 7, 10R, 10L, 11Rs, 11Ri, 11L.
Lymph Nodes Evaluated & Sampled:

Station 4R (Right Lower Paratracheal): The node was ≥ 10 mm on CT.
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics.
The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 2 elastographic pattern with mixed soft and stiff regions.
Given this heterogeneous and indeterminate appearance, TBNA was directed at representative areas.
The lymph node was photographed and the site was sampled;
8 endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained.

Station 11L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Station 11Rs: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

EBBX, TBBX
BAL
Station 4R - TBCBX, TBNA

Follow up in clinic.

The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Superior Segment of RLL (RB6).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.
Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle, 19-gauge Needle, and Cryoprobe 1.1mm.

Lymph Nodes Evaluated & Sampled:

Station 4L (Left Lower Paratracheal): The node was ≥ 10 mm on CT.
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics.
The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 3 elastographic pattern with predominantly stiff (blue).
Given this suspicious for malignancy or granuloma, TBNA was directed at representative areas.
The lymph node was photographed and the site was sampled;
8 endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained.

Station 11L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Station 10R: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)

31654 Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion 
76982 Ultrasound Elastography, First Target Lesion 
76983 Ultrasound Elastography, Additional Targets 

ATTENDING Dr. Smith

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope, Linear EBUS, Radial EBUS.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location.
Patient Position: Supine.

Initial Airway Inspection: NBI was used to assess the airway and nodular changes were noted.
Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the Lateral Segment of RML (RB4) and Medial Segment of RML (RB5).
Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.
Samples were sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.
Endobronchial Biopsy: Endobronchial biopsy was performed at LUL Carina (LC1/2) and LLL Carina (LC6).
Lesions were successfully removed and samples sent for Pathology.

Radial EBUS & Transbronchial Biopsy: Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the lesion in the RLL is concentric.
The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Superior Segment of RLL (RB6).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.
Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle, 19-gauge Needle, and Cryoprobe 1.1mm.
Lymph Nodes Inspected: 4R, 4L, 7, 10R, 10L, 11Rs, 11Ri, 11L.
Lymph Nodes Evaluated & Sampled:

Station 4L (Left Lower Paratracheal): The node was ≥ 10 mm on CT.
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics.
The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 3 elastographic pattern with predominantly stiff (blue).
Given this suspicious for malignancy or granuloma, TBNA was directed at representative areas.
The lymph node was photographed and the site was sampled;
8 endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained.

Station 11Rs: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Station 11L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

BAL
Station 4L - TBCBX, TBNA

Radial EBUS & Transbronchial Biopsy: Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the lesion in the RUL is concentric.
The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Apical Segment of RUL (RB1).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.

the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 52-year-old male who presents with mediastinal adenopathy and pulmonary nodules.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

R59.1 Generalized enlarged lymph nodes

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

R59.1 Generalized enlarged lymph nodes

PROCEDURE

31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s) 
31628 TBBX single lobe 
31652 EBUS sampling 1 or 2 nodes 
31654 Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion 
76982 Ultrasound Elastography, First Target Lesion 
76983 Ultrasound Elastography, Additional Targets 

ATTENDING Dr. Rodriguez

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope, Linear EBUS, Radial EBUS.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location.
Patient Position: Supine.

Initial Airway Inspection: NBI was used to assess the airway and nodular changes were noted.
Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the RUL Apical Segment (RB1).
Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.
Samples were sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.
Endobronchial Biopsy: Endobronchial biopsy was performed at LUL Carina (LC1/2) and LLL Carina (LC6).
Lesions were successfully removed and samples sent for Pathology.

Radial EBUS & Transbronchial Biopsy: Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the lesion in the RLL is concentric.
The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Superior Segment of RLL (RB6).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.
Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle, 19-gauge Needle, and Cryoprobe 1.1mm.
Lymph Nodes Inspected: 4R, 4L, 7, 10R, 10L, 11Rs, 11Ri, 11L.
Lymph Nodes Evaluated & Sampled:

Station 4L (Left Lower Paratracheal): The node was ≥ 10 mm on CT.
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics.
The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 2 elastographic pattern with mixed soft and stiff regions.
Given this heterogeneous and indeterminate appearance, TBNA was directed at representative areas.
The lymph node was photographed and the site was sampled;
8 endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained.

Station 11L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Station 4L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

EBBX, TBBX
BAL
Station 4L - TBCBX, TBNA 

IMPRESSION/PLAN

52-year-old male with mediastinal adenopathy and pulmonary nodules.

Follow up in clinic.

Initial Airway Inspection: NBI was used to assess the airway and nodular changes were noted.
Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the Lingula Superior (LB4) and Inferior (LB5).
Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.
Samples were sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.
Endobronchial Biopsy: Endobronchial biopsy was performed at RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2), and LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1).
Lesions were successfully removed and samples sent for Pathology.

Radial EBUS & Transbronchial Biopsy: Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the lesion in the LLL is concentric.
The following features were noted: Continuous margin; no vessels were noted.
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps at the Posterior-Basal Segment of LLL (LB10).
Total 6 samples were collected and sent for Pathology.

EBUS STAGING Indications: Diagnostic

Technique: All lymph node stations were assessed.
Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle, 19-gauge Needle, and Cryoprobe 1.1mm.
Lymph Nodes Inspected: 4R, 4L, 7, 10R, 10L, 11Rs, 11Ri, 11L.
Lymph Nodes Evaluated & Sampled:

Station 4R (Right Lower Paratracheal): The node was ≥ 10 mm on CT.
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics.
The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 3 elastographic pattern with predominantly stiff (blue).
Given this suspicious for malignancy or granuloma, TBNA was directed at representative areas.
The lymph node was photographed and the site was sampled;
8 endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained.

Station 4L: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Station 10R: The lymph node was < 10 mm on CT. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed;
the node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process.
The site was not sampled as it was not clinically indicated.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

EBBX, TBBX
BAL
Station 4R - TBCBX, TBNA

Follow up in clinic.
